item.title: France teen's family tell BBC police use of lethal force must change
item.description: One of Nahel's relatives says the riots do not honour Nahel's death, and the family want them to stop.

item.title: Energy boss says prices might spike this winter
item.description: Governments may need to give energy bill help this winter, says the head of the International Energy Agency.

item.title: NHS whistleblowers need more protection, expert warns
item.description: NHS whistleblowers are being victimised, risking another big hospital scandal, an expert tells the BBC.

item.title: Israeli strikes on Palestinian Jenin camp in West Bank
item.description: A large-scale Israeli military operation is under way in the northern West Bank city of Jenin.

item.title: Victoria Amelina: Ukrainian writer dies after Kramatorsk strike
item.description: Victoria Amelina, an award-winning writer, was in a pizza restaurant that was hit by a Russian missile.

item.title: Orkney council to look at proposals to become territory of Norway
item.description: The islands' councillors will consider a motion to investigate alternative forms of governance.

item.title: Lord's bosses suspend three members over clashes with Australia players
item.description: The Marylebone Cricket Club suspends three members over altercations with Australia players at Lord's on day five of the second Test.

item.title: Jess Phillips not racist, Labour frontbencher says amid online row
item.description: A senior headteacher accused Ms Phillips of racism and bullying following a Twitter row.

item.title: NHS England chief Amanda Pritchard says strike disruption will get worse
item.description: Amanda Pritchard told the BBC that July's strikes could be the worst yet for patients.

item.title: Nick Kyrgios: Australian withdraws from Wimbledon 2023 with wrist injury
item.description: Last year's men's singles runner-up Nick Kyrgios withdraws from Wimbledon 2023 with a wrist injury.

item.title: Watch: Mexican mayor weds crocodile in harvest ritual
item.description: The ceremony is part of an age-old ritual in which the reptile represents mother earth.

item.title: Baltimore shooting: Two dead and 28 injured in mass casualty event, police say
item.description: More than a dozen of the injured were under 18, a senior city official said, as suspects remain at large.

item.title: Rail disruption warning due to six-day train drivers' overtime ban
item.description: Fifteen train companies based in England will be hit from Monday until Saturday next week.

item.title: The Papers: Banks free speech warning and 'strikes until 2025'
item.description: A warning to banks over "blacklisting" customers and the prospect of more NHS strikes makes the papers.

item.title: Mystery of Holocaust escape girls solved after 84 years
item.description: For more than 80 years the identities of three girls captured in an iconic photograph were unknown.

item.title: Nauru: Why Australia is funding an empty detention centre
item.description: The last refugee has left Nauru, but Australia will keep spending vast sums to keep the centre open.

item.title: How AI can help process waste and increase recycling
item.description: Video cameras powered by AI are analysing work at waste processing and recycling facilities.

item.title: The false French riot posts spreading online
item.description: A number of false and misleading claims about the French riots have been circulating on social media.

item.title: John Shannon: 'I did things in the war I still can't talk about'
item.description: John Shannon was a school teacher before joining the Navy and being sent on secret missions.

item.title: Wagner: Russians reflect on group's advance towards Moscow
item.description: Russians have told the BBC they feared Wagner could unleash the violent tactics it uses in Ukraine on them.

item.title: Hachiko: The world's most loyal dog turns 100
item.description: The Akita Inu has been lionised in Japan and beyond as a symbol of devotion and fidelity.

item.title: Prince Harry, Piers Morgan and hacking: What did the bosses know?
item.description: Did knowledge of phone hacking by Mirror Group Newspapers journalists go right to the top?

item.title: California reparations: How do you put a price on racism?
item.description: The state of California is considering giving the descendants of slaves $1.2m each.

item.title: Ukraine finds British WW2 Hurricane planes outside Kyiv
item.description: London sent the Hawker Hurricanes to the Soviet Union to help them fight against Nazi Germany.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'aviation'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers around the world.

item.title: Water cremation: Co-op Funeralcare to be first UK company to offer resomation
item.description: The process, used in the US and Canada, will be available later this year through Co-op Funeralcare.

item.title: Big Thames Water investor backs turnaround plans
item.description: One of the UK's largest pension funds is the first investor to come out and support Thames Water.

item.title: Stephen Lawrence murder: Friend 'could have identified sixth suspect'
item.description: Duwayne Brooks, who witnessed the murder, says he could have picked a sixth suspect from a line-up.

item.title: Emmerdale and Coronation Street actress Meg Johnson dies
item.description: The soap stalwart, who appeared in Coronation Street, Emmerdale and Brookside, has died aged 86.

item.title: Spilled milk closes the M6 motorway after tanker crash
item.description: The M6 near Preston was closed for most of the day after milk spilled on to both carriageways.

item.title: Zulu King Misuzulu kaZwelithini treated for suspected poisoning - aide
item.description: The monarch's traditional prime minister says he is being treated in a hospital in Eswatini.

item.title: NHS England head urges football clubs to consider gambling ad impact
item.description: Clubs should think carefully before accepting sponsorship from gambling firms, says NHS England head.

item.title: Protests: Police powers to stop new tactics come into effect
item.description: Transport network disruption and tunnelling targeted under measures for police in England and Wales.

item.title: Cambridge flat fire: Woman and children named by police
item.description: Gemma Germeney, 31, Lilly Peden, eight, and Oliver Peden, four, all died in the fire, police say.

item.title: The Ashes: England v Australia - second Test, day five highlights
item.description: Ben Stokes' brilliant 155 is not enough to carry England to a second-Test victory over Australia at Lord's in one of the most incredible and controversial finishes in the history of the game.

item.title: Wimbledon 2023: Djokovic, Swiatek, Williams in action - day one preview
item.description: Novak Djokovic will open proceedings on Centre Court when Wimbledon 2023 gets under way on Monday.

item.title: The Ashes: England's Jonny Bairstow is stumped by Alex Carey
item.description: England's Jonny Bairstow is controversially stumped by Australia's wicket-keeper Alex Carey on day five of the second Test at Lord's.

item.title: Neita beats Asher-Smith in Stockholm, protesters hit Warholm's race
item.description: Daryll Neita wins the women's 200m ahead of fellow Briton Dina Asher-Smith at a rainy Diamond League meeting in Stockholm.

item.title: Wimbledon 2023: Brain games and conscious breathing - the secrets of Djokovic’s success
item.description: Novak Djokovic is famous for his dedication and meticulous preparation, but he may let some of his strict routines slip as he tries to defend his Wimbledon title.

item.title: Wimbledon 2023: Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, Elena Rybakina, Katie Boulter among stars
item.description: With Wimbledon starting on Monday, BBC Sport looks at the key themes going into one of the highlights of the British sporting summer.

item.title: Paris riots: Suburban mayor's wife hurt as rioters attack their home
item.description: Attackers tried to set the house on fire before firing rockets at the mayor's fleeing wife and children.

item.title: French teen shooting: Piecing together what happened
item.description: Prosecutors are due to interview a witness after he posted a version of events online.

item.title: France shooting: Calmer night despite protests over Nahel M's murder, minister says
item.description: A total of 719 people were arrested as disturbances gripped Marseille and other cities with Paris quieter.

item.title: France shooting: Who was Nahel M, shot by French police in Nanterre?
item.description: He was learning to be an electrician and played rugby league but died at a police check near Paris.

item.title: France riots: Why are police using guns during traffic stops?
item.description: Nahel M's death follows an increase in police using firearms on drivers who fail to stop.

item.title: France riots: Nanterre rocked by killing and unrest
item.description: The town of Nanterre is shaken by nights of rioting after 17-year-old Nahel was shot by police.

item.title: France riots: Marseille gun shop looted amid fears of increased violence
item.description: A gun shop in Marseille was looted on Friday amid fears looting and violence will get worse on Saturday.

item.title: France shooting: Macron accuses rioters of exploiting teen killed by police
item.description: At a crisis meeting, France's president condemns three nights of riots as "unjustifiable".

item.title: France shooting: How a teenager's death sparked riots
item.description: The death of 17-year-old Nahel M, during a traffic stop, has provoked anger across the country.

item.title: France shooting: Policeman charged over teen's traffic stop death
item.description: France sees a third night of mass unrest, triggered by Tuesday's police shooting of a teenager.

item.title: What we know about the killing... in 55 seconds
item.description: The BBC's Hugh Schofield investigates at the scene where police shot dead 17-year-old Nahel.

item.title: Mother of teenage boy speaks after Paris police shooting
item.description: Seventeen-year-old Nahel M was shot by police during a traffic stop in Nanterre, a suburb of Paris.

item.title: Macron's solidarity seems to fall on deaf ears among locals
item.description: Some residents of Nanterre are bracing for a long cold war between French suburbs and the state.
